name: Marcella Hazan's Bolognese Sauce
processes: Put the vegetable oil, 3 tablespoons of butter, and chopped onion in a heavy-bottomed pot over medium heat.
Cook and stir the onion until it becomes translucent.
Add the chopped celery and carrot, and cook for about 2 minutes, stirring to coat the vegetables well.
Add the ground beef, a large pinch of salt, and a few grindings of black pepper. Crumble the meat with a fork, stir well, and cook until the beef has lost its raw red color.
Add the whole milk and let it simmer gently, stirring frequently, until it has bubbled away completely and evaporated.
Add a tiny grating, approximately 1/8 teaspoon, of whole nutmeg, and stir.
Add the dry white wine and let it simmer until it has evaporated.
Add the canned imported Italian plum tomatoes and stir thoroughly to coat all ingredients well.
When the tomatoes begin to bubble, turn the heat down so that the sauce cooks at the laziest of simmers, with just an intermittent bubble breaking through to the surface.
Cook, uncovered, for at least 3 hours or more, stirring from time to time.
If the sauce begins to dry out, add 1/2 cup of water whenever necessary to keep it from sticking. At the end, no water should be left and the fat must separate from the sauce.
Taste and correct for salt.
Serve hot, tossed with cooked drained pasta and the remaining 1 tablespoon of butter, and with freshly grated Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese at the table.

name: Slow-Roasted Crispy Pork Belly
processes: Score the skin of the pork belly lightly in a crosshatch pattern, being careful not to cut into the meat.
Pat the pork belly skin thoroughly dry with paper towels.
Place the pork belly, skin-side up, on a wire rack set over a baking sheet and refrigerate uncovered overnight (at least 8 hours, up to 24 hours) to dry out the skin.
On the day of cooking, remove the pork belly from the fridge and allow it to come to room temperature for about 30 minutes.
Preheat your oven to 150°C (300°F).
Rub the flesh side of the pork belly with 10 ml olive oil, 10 grams salt, and 3 grams black pepper.
Turn the pork belly skin-side up. Rub the skin thoroughly with an additional 10 ml olive oil and 5 grams salt, ensuring the salt is worked into the scored lines.
Place the pork belly, skin-side up, on the wire rack set over a rimmed baking sheet.
Slow roast in the preheated oven for 3 hours.
Remove the pork belly from the oven and carefully pour off any rendered fat from the baking sheet.
Increase the oven temperature to 230°C (450°F).
Return the pork belly to the oven and roast for another 20-30 minutes, or until the skin is puffed, golden brown, and crispy. Watch carefully to prevent burning.
Remove from the oven and let the pork belly rest for 15 minutes before carving and serving.

name: Shepherd's Pie
processes: Preheat oven to 200°C (400°F).
Peel and dice potatoes. Place them in a large pot, cover with cold salted water, and bring to a boil. Cook for 15-20 minutes, or until fork-tender.
While potatoes cook, in a large oven-safe skillet or Dutch oven, brown the ground meat over medium-high heat. Break it up with a spoon as it cooks. Drain any excess fat.
Add diced onions and carrots to the skillet with the meat. Cook, stirring occasionally, until vegetables soften, about 5-7 minutes.
Stir in the tomato paste and flour, cooking for 1 minute.
Gradually pour in the beef broth and Worcestershire sauce. Bring to a simmer, stirring constantly, and cook until the sauce thickens, about 5 minutes.
Stir in the frozen peas. Season the meat mixture with salt and black pepper to taste.
Once potatoes are cooked, drain them well. Mash them with butter and milk until smooth and creamy. Season with salt and pepper.
Pour the meat mixture into a 2-quart baking dish (if not using an oven-safe skillet).
Evenly spread the mashed potatoes over the meat mixture, using a fork to create decorative peaks.
Bake for 25-30 minutes, or until the potato topping is golden brown and the filling is bubbly.
Let the shepherd's pie rest for 5-10 minutes before serving.
